Cresselia.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Calm Mind.description:
• Cresselia is the bulkiest option avaliable for a Calm Mind user.

  • Stored Power takes time to gain power, but after 2 Calm Minds, it becomes Cresselia's most powerful STAB attack. Psyshock can be used to defeat Tapu Fini in Calm Mind wars if they lack Taunt, win against Raikou, and deal massive damage to Nihilego.

  • Ice Beam hits a lot of high value targets hard, such as Landorus-T, Salamence, and Garchomp. Moonblast still does good damage to Dragon-types, and makes Cresselia less vulnerable to Dark-types like Urshifu-S.

  • Substitute allows Cresselia to set up in the face of status users such as Celesteela, Swampert, and Hippowdon that lack Whirlwind. However, this makes Cresselia completely useless against Dark-types, so don't choose it in team preview if they are seen.

Items

  • Kee Berry's Defense boost helps Cresselia against powerful Dynamaxing threats such as Cinderace and Landorus-T, all while giving another 20 BP boost to Stored Power.

  • Sitrus Berry gives Cresselia a short burst of extra health, making it more difficult to break past in the short term.

  • Leftovers gives more long-term recovery, which is helpful in slower-paced matches.

  • Rocky Helmet is useful for punishing Pokemon that commoningly use physical contact moves, such as Cinderace and Urshifu-R.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Bold / 4 Spe Bold: This spread maximizes Cresselia's physical bulk.

  • 252 HP / 100 Def / 156 Spe Bold: This spread is suggested for Substitute Cresselia. It outspeeds up to Timid Celesteela, allowing Cresselia to set up Substitute before Celesteela hits with Leech Seed.

Trick Room Support.description:
• Cresselia is an extremely bulky option for Trick Room, and with Lunar Dance, it's the only viable one that can give Trick Room sweepers another chance at sweeping.

  • Psychic is a reliable STAB option if Cresselia needs to do some damage, but Ice Beam hits a wide variety of targets harder such as Landorus-T, Salamence, and Garchomp.

  • Even though this Cresselia often sacrifces itself with Lunar Dance, Moonlight is still good to have to potentially wall certain Pokemon.

  • When using this Cresselia, always pair it with 1-2 slow Pokemon that can take advantage of Trick Room. Glastrier is by far the most dangerous Trick Room sweeper, so it comes highly recommended. Other options for slow Pokemon include Celesteela, Heatran, Magnezone, and Ferrothorn.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry gives Cresselia a quick burst of recovery. This is more valuable than Leftovers, since Cresselia often sacrifices itself anyways.

  • Rocky Helmet is still good for punishing contact moves from common foes such as Cinderace and Urshifu-R.

Zacian-Crowned.overview: These sets are for one of the final Battle Stadium Singles metagames for this generation. If you feel there is anything wrong or missing, please post in this thread.

All-out Attacker.description:
EV Spreads

  • 236 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 12 Spe with Adamant: This bulky EV spread maximizes Zacian-C's power, while still outspeeding Garchomp.

  • 236 HP / 180 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 84 Spe with Adamant: This spread outspeeds Timid Lugia at the cost of some power.

  • 236 HP / 92 Atk / 4 Def / 164 SpD / 12 Spe with Adamant:: This Specially Defensive spread survives Modest Life Orb Yveltal's Max Flare and Timid Choice Scarf Kyogre's Water Spout.

  • 252 Atk / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Jolly: Maximizing Speed allows Zacian-C to outspeed Eternatus and Marshadow, at the cost of having the bulk to effectively trade blows.

Swords Dance Sweeper.description:
EV Spreads

  • 252 Atk / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Jolly: Maximizing Speed lets Zacian-C defeat Marshadow with Stealth Rock support, outspeed Eternatus, and is the best bet against opposing Zacian-C after Swords Dance.

  • 236 HP / 180 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 84 Spe with Adamant: This spread sacrifices some power to survive Focus Sash Landorus-T's Earthquake, and still outspeed Timid Lugia.

Clefable.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Kee Berry Sweeper.description:
• This Clefable aims to take advantage of opposing setup sweepers in order to augment its own stats and reverse sweep.

  • Moonlight is chosen to guarantee quick healing and for getting boosted healing in sun, which can be set by Clefable's own Max Flare. Be wary of its low PP and other weathers before committing to sweeping and relying on it for healing.

  • Kee Berry is used to grant Clefable a one-time boost of Defense and can be used in combination with Dynamax to ensure Clefable can survive hits such as Excadrill's Iron Head.

  • The given EV spread gives near maximum physical bulk and is used to survive an initial physical hit as well as possible before getting the +1 Defense boost from Kee Berry.

Trick Crippler.description:
• Clefable when equipped with Flame Orb or Lagging Tail can cripple various attackers, making them easy setup fodder for teammates.

  • Stealth Rock provides additional support, but can be sacrificed for Flamethrower coverage, in order to ensure Ferrothorn and Celesteela cannot switch in with impunity.

Items

  • Flame Orb allows Clefable to cripple physical attackers with Trick.

  • Lagging Tail and Full Incense are an extremely effective form of Speed control with Trick, with even fast Pokemon, and Pokemon under Trick Room being impacted by it.

  • Leftovers can also be opted for, and provides a decent all around Stealth Rock lead with two useful complementary attacks.

Chansey.overview: These sets are for one of the final Battle Stadium Singles metagames for this generation. If you feel there is anything wrong or missing, please post in this thread.

Gyarados.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Offensive.description:
• Gyarados's combination of unique typing and movepool make it a good choice for Max Airstream sweeping.

  • Dragon Dance is a great option on Gyarados, making it less reliant on Dynamax to sweep.

  • Power Whip provides coverage against bulky Water-types, most notably slamming Rotom-W, Tapu Fini, and Swampert.

  • Earthquake deals massive damage to Electric-types such as Raikou, Tapu Koko, and Magnezone, while giving Gyarados a valuable Special Defense boost as Max Quake.

  • Taunt deserves special mention for shutting down passive Pokemon such as Hippowdon, Swampert, and defensive Celesteela, giving Life Orb Gyarados more set up opportunities.

  • Ice Fang is also a reasonable coverage option, hitting Dragon-types such as Garchomp, Salamence, and Dragonite much more effectively.

  • Stone Edge is Gyarados's strongest option against Zapdos.

  • Intimidate is a good choice for allowing Gyarados to set up Dragon Dance more freely, while Moxie allows Gyarados to potentially sweep with just KOs from Max Airstream.

  • A Jolly nature and the given EV spread ensures that Gyarados outspeeds Tapu Koko and Dragapult after a Speed boost.

Items

  • Lum Berry insulates Gyarados from status such as Sleep and Burn. When used with Dragon Dance, this makes Gyarados an effective lead against Hippowdon and Swampert.

  • Life Orb makes Gyarados an effective Dynamax sweeper, and should always be used if Gyarados gives up Dragon Dance for more coverage.

  • Wacan Berry is a less common option for Gyarados that lets it survive some Electric-type attacks while Dynamaxed.

Bulky Dragon Dance.description:
• This Gyarados takes a slower approach to sweeping, and uses increased bulk and Intimidate to better check major threats.

  • Taunt is extremely useful for punishing passive Pokemon that Gyarados may otherwise have trouble setting up on, such as Hippowdon, Swampert, and defensive Celesteela.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry is a good, reliable way for Gyarados to gain back a short burst of health.

  • When paired with Chesto Berry, Rest is useful for giving Gyarados a second chance at sweeping later, at the cost of immediate recovery that Sitrus Berry provides.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 156 Def / 100 Spe with Impish: This EV spread allows Gyarados to outspeed Nihilego with one Speed boost, and avoid a 2HKO from Life Orb Cinderace's Max Airstream with Sitrus Berry after Stealth Rock damage.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish: This EV spread maximizes Gyarados's physical bulk.

  • 156 HP / 164 Def / 188 Spe with Impish: This EV spread outspeeds Timid Celesteela, while still giving Gyarados a 95% chance to avoid a 2HKO from Cinderace's Life Orb Max Airstream after Stealth Rock and Sitrus Berry.

  • 252 HP / 132 Atk / 20 Def / 4 SpD / 100 Spe with Adamant: This is a more offensive approach for Gyarados, allowing it to survive two Max Airstreams from Life Orb Cinderace after Sitrus Berry, and outspeed Nihilego after one Speed boost

  • 252 HP / 20 Def / 4 SpD / 232 Spe with Jolly: This EV spread allows Gyarados to outspeed up to Timid Dragapult and Tapu Koko after one Speed boost, while being able to avoid a 2HKO from Life Orb Cinderace's Max Airstream after Sitrus Berry.

Lapras-Gmax.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: A Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are fantastic in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame, and can sweep, support, or wall significant portions of the metagame. These Pokemon require less support than most others to be used effectively and have few flaws that can easily be overlooked when compared to their positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

G-Max Resonance.description:
• Lapras functions as a solid special tank that has the niche of being able to take on opposing Water-types like Swampert and offensive Tapu Fini, thanks to its natural bulk, ability, typing, and access to Freeze-Dry.

  • Sheer Cold allows Lapras to defeat natural checks like Porygon2 and Chansey while also doing more damage with G-Max Resonance than Freeze Dry. Thunder instead gives Lapras a powerful coverage option against Water-type Pokemon and Celesteela when Dynamaxed.

  • The last moveslot can be used for Ice Shard, which gives Lapras access to STAB priority, or for Electric-type coverage if it hasn't been included in previous moveslots.

Items

  • Weakness Policy is a great fit for G-Max Resonance, patching up Lapras's disappointing offensive stats and letting it sweep.

  • Assault Vest makes Lapras more valuable outside of Dynamax, making it a bulky abuser of Sheer Cold.

  • Light Clay increases G-Max Resonance's effects for an extra 3 turns, making Gigantamax Lapras even more difficult to break through.

Ditto.overview: This set is for one of the final Battle Stadium Singles metagames for this generation. If you feel there is anything wrong or missing, please post in this thread.

Revenge Killer.description:
Items

  • Choice Scarf: This is the best option for revenge killing with Ditto.

  • Focus Sash: While very weak to Stealth Rock set up, being able to switch moves can make Ditto more effective at reverse sweeping without needing to Dynamax.

Snorlax-Gmax.overview:
Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Gmax Setup Sweeper.description:
• Snorlax can use Belly Drum or Curse to raise its stats to frightening levels and break many Pokemon who would otherwise wall it.

  • Heavy Slam and Earthquake are both great coverage choices in the Crown Tundra metagame, and when using them with Gigantamax, it allows Snorlax to boost its Defense and Special Defense with their respective Max Moves.

  • Figy Berry helps Snorlax gain back significant health when dropped below half HP, and can also be restored with Gmax Replenish.

EV Spreads

  • 220 HP / 212 Def / 76 SpD Careful: This spread deals with prominent Special Attack boosting foes, such as Nihilego, and helps Snorlax wall with both its physical and special bulk.

  • 212 HP / 252 Def / 52 Spe Impish: Outspeeds Toxapex to avoid getting hit by Haze following a Belly Drum.

Yawn Support.description:
• Snorlax is a solid Yawn abuser, living nearly all Max Move attacks at full HP to guarantee disruption to its foes.

  • Heavy Slam allows Snorlax to hit the relevant Ghost-types well and boosts Defense with Max Steelspike, while Earthquake hits Nihilego and Heatran well, and raises Special Defense with Max Quake.

  • Leftovers is used with Thick Fat, regular form Snorlax, and Protect, as those have the most impact when no berry is held. Figy Berry is used with Gluttony and Gigantamax in order to gain back health when in a pinch, and can also be restored with Gmax Replenish or Recycle.

Zapdos.overview:
Viability Ranking: S

Reserved for the best Pokemon in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon are usually able to perform a variety of roles effectively, or can just do one extremely well. Their use has low risk involved and high reward exerted. Pokemon in this rank have very few flaws that are patched up by numerous positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Dynamax Attacker.description:
• Zapdos makes an excellent Dynamax Attacker thanks to its STAB Max Airstream and great natural bulk.

  • Thunderbolt is the most reliable Electric-type STAB option for Zapdos to get high damage output. Volt Switch isn't as powerful while Dynamaxed, but allows Zapdos to pivot and bait out common switch-ins if it does not wish to Dynamax.

  • Heat Wave gives Zapdos useful coverage, but can be replaced with Substitute to bait out status moves, such as Hippowdon's Yawn.

  • Roost is generally always included to keep Zapdos healthy and give it access to Max Guard. While quite rare, Steel Wing on an all-out-attacking set can surprise traditional counters such as Nihilego, and allows you to beat most variants of Mimikyu as well with accumulating Defense boosts from Max Steelspike.

  • Static is best for potentially punishing contact moves with paralysis, since the set is unlikely to survive long enough for Pressure to be particularly useful. However, Pressure can still be used on this set to reveal less about your Zapdos's intentions and stall out moves with very low PP.

  • Timid is usually the best nature for Zapdos, allowing it to outspeed key threats such as Mimikyu and Urshifu. However, Modest gives it a major power boost otherwise.

Items

  • Life Orb is highly recommended for maximizing Zapdos's power while Dynamaxed.

  • If another Pokemon is already holding Life Orb, Sharp Beak is a reasonable alternative to boost Max Airstream.

Defensive.description:
• A bulky variant of Zapdos is useful for continually sponging hits and being able to serve as a multi-purpose pivot.

  • While Volt Switch is most commonly opted to retain momentum, Thunderbolt and Discharge are both very reasonable alternative options to maintain Electric offensive pressure.

  • Heat Wave gives Zapdos useful coverage to help it hit more targets effectively when it comes in, however, Eerie Impulse gives Zapdos more defensive flexibility and allows it to shut down special attacking Dynamax threats. Thunder Wave is useful for slowing down foes for teammates.

  • The given EVs allow Zapdos to outspeed key threats after a Max Airstream, such as Jolly Cinderace and Adamant Choice Scarf Dracovish, while maximizing its physical bulk.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet pairs well with Zapdos's longevity, effectively punishing Pokemon that use contact moves such as Urshifu-R.

  • Sitrus and Wiki Berry allow Zapdos to gain back HP to survive and stall out weaker Dynamax attacks.

Defensive Kee Berry.description:
• Kee Berry allows for Zapdos to beat almost every physical attacker that does not resist its dual STAB combination, effectively stalling out a variety of opposing Dynamax options.

  • Discharge is opted for in order to status opponents to win over a long period of time. However, in a pure stall scenario without a timer, Thunderbolt can be opted for so that the opponent loses less turns from Paralysis lock and is forced to use its PP.

  • Eerie Impulse allows Zapdos to get the best of special attacking threats, becoming nearly unbreakable after repeated uses. It also has high PP, which is useful for stalling turns.

  • Heat Wave can be used to gain greater offensive coverage options, which is particularly useful for beating out Ferrothorn.

  • This set's EV spreads allow Zapdos to outspeed Adamant Dracovish, and outspeed Jolly Cinderace after one use of Max Airstream.

Choice Attacker.description:
• Zapdos with a Choice item provides an element of surprise, sporting either a very fast or very strong pivot option, which allows it to get a momentum advantage against serious threats to it, such as Tyranitar and Nihilego.

  • Volt Switch is most often opted for due to its far superior damage output, but U-turn can be used on the Choice Scarf set to not get immunity locked against Ground-types like Hippowdon.

  • Heat Wave is the chosen coverage option in order to OHKO Excadrill and Magnezone with a Choice Specs boosted attack, two otherwise potent checks to Zapdos' STAB combination.

  • Static is the most useful ability for potential paralysis, but Pressure does a good job of disguising Zapdos's true role to your foe.

Zapdos-Galar.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B- Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Dynamax Sweeper.description:
• Galarian Zapdos has the tools to be a decent Max Airstream sweeper, though its poor match-up against other Max Airstream sweepers limits its potential.

  • Close Combat is Galarian Zapdos's most powerful STAB. Thunderous Kick's Defense drop does play better to hit and run tactics, however.

  • Brave Bird is the obvious choice for a strong Max Airstream, but Dual Wingbeat can be useful for busting through Urshifu-R's Focus Sash after a boost, and dealing damage through Mimikyu's Disguise.

  • Bulk Up is Galarian Zapdos's only means to set up outside of Dynamax, and can be key to helping it survive unfavorable physical match-ups with the Defense boost.

  • Blaze Kick is Galarian Zapdos's strongest attack against Celesteela if Dynamaxed.

  • Taunt punishes passive Pokemon like Hippowdon, Swampert, and Ferrothorn.

  • U-turn can make Galarian Zapdos a decent pivot.

Items

  • Weakness Policy works well with Dynamax, especially considering how many weaknesses Galarian Zapdos has.

  • Life Orb is a good alternative that doesn't put as much pressure on Dynamaxing.

  • Lum Berry protects Galarian Zapdos from status, making it more difficult to stop while Dynamaxed.

Choice Attacker.description:
• Galarian Zapdos has a good enough Speed tier and offenses to make a decent Choice Attacker. It also has access to U-turn, which is useful for pivoting.

  • Close Combat is the obvious choice for a strong Fighting-type STAB, but Thunderous Kick's guaranteed Defense drop can come in handy if Galarian Zapdos must switch out.

  • Brave Bird is the prefered choice for a Flying-type STAB, but Dual Wingbeat is a reasonable option to hit through Focus Sash and Mimikyu's disguise.

  • Blaze Kick is Galarian Zapdos's strongest option against Celesteela while Dynamaxed.

Items

  • Choice Scarf lets Galarian Zapdos outspeed several key threats, such as Pheromosa and Dragapult.

  • Choice Band makes Galarian Zapdos harder to switch in to, most notably 2HKOing defensive Tapu Fini with Brave Bird.

Focus Sash.description:
• With Counter and Focus Sash, Galarian Zapdos can surprise common problematic Max Airstream users such as Cinderace and Landorus-T with a KO.

  • Close Combat is an easy choice with its high power, but Thunderous Kick benefits hit and run tactics more.

  • Since Galarian Zapdos is using Focus Sash, Dual Wingbeat is the best choice for a Flying-type STAB.

  • U-turn allows Galarian Zapdos to pivot out of unfavorable match-ups, but Taunt is useful for shutting down Stealth Rock set up from more passive Pokemon. Bulk Up can give Galarian Zapdos the Attack boost it needs to pull off a surprise late-game sweep.

Moltres-Galar.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: A Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are fantastic in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame, and can sweep, support, or wall significant portions of the metagame. These Pokemon require less support than most others to be used effectively and have few flaws that can easily be overlooked when compared to their positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Dynamax Sweeper.description:
• Galarian Moltres is a deceptively powerful and bulky Max Airstream sweeper, thanks to Berserk and its excellent offensive typing.

  • Hurricane is Galarian Moltres's most powerful sweeping option while Dynamaxed, but Air Slash is more reliable when not Dynamaxed.

  • Taunt is a versatile support option that lets Galarian Moltres set up on prominent passive Pokemon, such as Hippowdon and Toxapex.

  • Sucker Punch, while weak, can pick off weakened threats.

  • Rest gives Galarian Moltres another chance of sweeping if used with Chesto Berry.

  • A Modest nature is prefered to give Galarian Moltres as much power as possible, but Timid does guarantee that Galarian Moltres outspeeds certain threats that hang around the base 80 Speed range, such as Dragonite, Gyarados, and Rotom-W.

Items

  • Weakness Policy makes Galarian Moltres an even bigger threat under Dynamax, letting Galarian Moltres feasibly get up to +5 Special Attack thanks to Nasty Plot and Berserk.

  • Sitrus Berry gives Galarian Moltres a longer shelf life.

  • Lum Berry is excellent for punishing Yawn leads such as Hippowdon and Swampert. If using Rest, Chesto Berry is the prefered option.

Dragonite.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: A Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are fantastic in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame, and can sweep, support, or wall significant portions of the metagame. These Pokemon require less support than most others to be used effectively and have few flaws that can easily be overlooked when compared to their positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Physical Sweeper.description:
• Dragonite makes a fearsome bulky sweeper thanks to Multiscale and access to a STAB Max Airstream.

  • Outside of its dual STAB attack options, Fire Punch helps defeat Ferrothorn and Celesteela, while Ice Punch can be used to help deal with Landorus-T. Max Hailstorm is also particularly useful for KOing many common Focus Sash Pokemon in one turn.

  • Dragon Dance gives Dragonite an alternate means to set up besides Weakness Policy, and Roost allows Dragonite to retain its Multiscale throughout the course of a game, allowing it to fish for missed attacks and stall out low PP moves.

  • The given EVs outspeed Cinderace at +1, ensure Porygon2 gains an Attack boost from Download, and otherwise gives Dragonite a good bulk-power balance.

Items

  • Weakness Policy makes Dragonite a daunting foe to face while Dynamaxed, and perfectly takes advantage of Multiscale.

  • Lum Berry can be used with Dragon Dance to protect Dragonite against status.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots allows Dragonite to retain its Multiscale even if Stealth Rock is set up.

Bulky Stall.description:
• With the use of Heavy Duty Boots, Dragonite can ensure it always comes in without breaking Multiscale, allowing it to stall out a variety of opponents that cannot break it while using special coverage to wear down foes unable to recover or resist its coverage.

  • Outside of Hurricane as its main STAB, this Dragonite runs Ice Beam to hit Landorus-T, Zapdos, and opposing Dragon-types super effectively, and Fire Blast to hit Ferrothorn, Celesteela, and Glastrier.

  • The given EVs are designed to maximize Dragonite's physical bulk while outspeeding neutral nature base 100 Speed Pokemon at +1.

Maranga Sweeper.description:
• When equipped with a Maranga Berry, Dragonite is able to effectively stall or set up on a variety of special attackers after receiving a Special Defense boost.

  • Dual Wingbeat is necessary for achieving Speed boosts with Max Airstream if Dragonite is not able to safely Dragon Dance. The added HP from Dynamax allows Dragonite to trigger Maranga Berry more safely. The Speed boost allows Dragonite to Roost to maximum HP before taking a hit from a foe after Dynamax expires.

  • Dragon Dance and Roost work in combination to stall while slowly setting up boosts to overwhelm special attackers who cannot break Dragonite.

  • The choice between Outrage and Fire Punch depends on what coverage Dragonite's teammate are equipped with. Outrage allows Dragonite to beat other Dragon-types and has higher base power, while Fire Punch helps defeat Steel-types who could otherwise handle it, such as Kartana and Celesteela.

Wallbreaker.description:
• Dragonite can equip a damage boosting item to wallbreak unsuspecting foes, allowing it to catch opponents off guard that suspect it to boost with Dragon Dance or those that try to play around Weakness Policy.

  • Dual Wingbeat is necessary to increase Speed through Max Airstream; however, the other moves are open to adjustment based on the team's needs.

  • Outrage is Dragonite's strongest attack and hits opposing Dragon-types hard, however, it comes with the downside of being locked into and Fairy-types being immune to it. Alternatively, Ice Punch can be used instead, which sports better type coverage while also hitting Landorus-T super effectively.

  • Thunder Punch is helpful against Water-types, Tapu Fini in particular, as it allows Dragonite to wallbreak them when using Max Lightning. Fire Punch can be opted for instead to hit Steel-types such as Kartana and Ferrothorn.

  • In the last move slot, Superpower allows Dragonite to gain Attack boosts when Dynamaxed, Extreme Speed is particularly useful for picking off weakened opponents and synergizes well with Choice Band, and Earthquake beats Heatran while also boosting Special Defense as Max Quake.

Items

  • Inner Focus is most often used with Life Orb, as it allows Dragonite to avoid Intimidate from Pokemon such as Landorus-T, and because the recoil from Life Orb removes the benefits from Multiscale.

  • If using Choice Band, Multiscale is still preferred, and Choice Band makes up for the damage output loss from Intimidate.

Azumarill.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Bad Bunny (Huge Power Wallbreaker).description:
• Azumarill is an uncommon but unique wallbreaker in Battle Stadium, with decent bulk, useful dual STAB coverage, and a great priority move to beat much of the metagame that doesn't resist its attacks.

  • Superpower gives Azumarill a way to beat Ferrothorn while providing Max Knuckle Attack boosts during Dynamax, whereas Bounce is used with Life Orb to help Azumarill become a surprise sweeper.

  • The given EVs allow Azumarill to have decent bulk while outspeeding uninvested Celesteela, and avoiding a Special Attack boost from Download Porygon2. The leftover 4 EVs can be put anywhere but Defense.

Items

  • Assault Vest makes Azumarill quite bulky, especially while Dynamaxed.

  • Choice Band makes Azumarill an effective hit and run attacker.

  • Life Orb, while compromising Azumarill's bulk, is the most effective wall-breaking tool for it, making Azumarill a good Dynamax attacker.

Quagsire.overview: This set is for one of the final Battle Stadium Singles metagames for this generation. If you feel there is anything wrong or missing, please post in this thread.

Umbreon.overview: This set is for a new and developing metagame. If you have any questions about the set, feel free to ask any in the Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Discussion thread.

KINGSLAYER (Defensive Support).description:
• With its good bulk, Yawn, and STAB Foul Play, Umbreon has a small niche as an answer to both Calyrex-S and Calyrex-I.

  • Foul Play provides consistent damage, puts heavy pressure on Calyrex-S thanks to its quadruple weakness, and can do decent damage to Zacian-C trying to come in.

  • Snarl is less useful against Calyrex-I, but it can completely shut down Calyrex-S, as well as annoying most special threats thanks to the Special Attack drop.

  • Moonlight can be used in place of Wish for instant, though inconsistent, recovery.

  • Though Umbreon should only Dynamax in the most dire of situations, a Careful nature will make Max Darkness slightly stronger.

Items

  • Leftovers is the most sensible item, granting Umbreon consistent passive recovery, lessening the need to use Wish and Protect.

  • Sitrus Berry is an alternative to Leftovers, providing Umbreon with a quick burst of health after taking some damage.

  • Utility Umbrella can allow Umbreon to better stand up to Kyogre, and it also enables more consistent recovery if using Moonlight. However, even with Utility Umbrella, Umbreon should not be relied on as a Kyogre answer.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpD with Calm - This spread maximizes Umbreon’s special bulk, allowing it to consistently check Calyrex-S.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with Bold - This spread allows Umbreon to better take physical attacks but severely hinders its consistency against Calyrex-S and other special threats.

Skarmory.overview: This set is for a new and developing metagame. If you have any questions about the set, feel free to ask any in the Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Discussion thread.

Porygon2.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: A+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are fantastic in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame, and can sweep, support, or wall significant portions of the metagame. These Pokemon require less support than most others to be used effectively and have few flaws that can easily be overlooked when compared to their positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Defensive.description:
• With recovery, BoltBeam coverage, and impressive defensive stats, Porygon2 is one of the best walls in the metagame.

  • Porygon2 has a highly contested final moveslot. Offensively, Tri Attack is a reliable STAB attack that does good damage to most switch-ins. Foul Play allows Porygon2 to punish Pokemon that boost their Attack stat, such as Mimikyu. Although seemingly odd, Giga Impact allows Porygon2 to effectively take advantage of an Attack boost from Download, surprising Calm Mind setters like Tapu Fini and Raikou with a boosted Max Strike after Dynamaxing.

  • For final support options, Trick Room is a highly effective way to support slow sweepers such as Glastrier, Celesteela, and Rhyperior. Substitute protects Porygon2 from status such as Leech Seed and Sleep. Thunder Wave is a more consistent option for paralysis spreading than Discharge.

  • Download gives Porygon2 a decent offensive presence, making it the prefered option. Trace is a usable alternative for punishing Intimidate Pokemon such as Landorus-T, and copying other useful abilities such as Beast Boost.

EV Spreads

  • 244 HP / 252 Def / 12 SpD with Bold: This spread allows Porygon2 to be an effective physical wall, useful against a wide variety of threats such as Landorus-T and Dragapult.

  • 244 HP / 12 Def / 252 SpD with Calm: This spread makes Porygon2 a great special wall, making it a good check against threats such as Zapdos and Galarian Moltres.

  • 244 HP / 232 Def / 32 Spe with Bold: Defensive Thunder Wave Porygon2 should use this spread to outspeed base 100 Speed Pokemon after paralysis.

  • 244 HP / 232 SpD / 32 Spe with Calm: Specially defensive Thunder Wave Porygon2 should use this spread to outspeed base 100 Speed Pokemon after paralysis.

  • 244 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Def / 4 SpD / 4 Spe with Relaxed: Physically defensive Porygon2 with Giga Impact should use this spread for dealing good damage with a boosted Max Strike.

  • 244 HP / 4 Atk / 4 Def /252 SpD / 4 Spe with Sassy: Specially defensive Porygon2 with Giga Impact should use this spread to deal good damage with Max Strike.

Offensive.description:
• Thanks to Download, Porygon2 is a very effective bulky offensive threat.

  • Tri Attack is a great offensive option due to being a reliable STAB that hits most Pokemon neutrally. Alternately, Giga Impact makes Porygon2 a shockingly good mixed Dynamax sweeper that punishes Calm Mind Pokemon such as Raikou and Tapu Fini. Hyper Beam is a decent alternate option for a strong Max Strike while Dynamaxed as well.

  • Trick Room is an incredible support option that not only makes bulky sweepers such as Glastrier and Rhyperior much more deadly, but Porygon2 itself is fully capable of sweeping under it. Speed Swap is an interesting alternative that severely punishes fast Pokemon that stay in against Porygon2.

  • Porygon2 has many combinations of Attacks to consider, depending on the make-up of your team. When using Giga Impact, Porygon2 should always pair it with Ice Beam so it doesn't lose to Landorus-T. Porygon2 can function without a Normal-type STAB since boltbeam coverage hits so many Pokemon hard, but it does make it a more passive Pokemon. A Normal STAB and Thunderbolt offers good coverage, but can be annoyed by Dragapult who resists that combination.

Blissey.overview: This set is for one of the final Battle Stadium Singles metagames for this generation. If you feel there is anything wrong or missing, please post in this thread.

Raikou.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: A- Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are fantastic in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame, and can sweep, support, or wall significant portions of the metagame. These Pokemon require less support than most others to be used effectively and have few flaws that can easily be overlooked when compared to their positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Calm Mind.description:
• Raikou's great Speed stat and shockingly good coverage make it a good choice for Calm Mind sweeping.

  • Substitute pairs very well with Pressure for PP stalling, punishes more flimsy checks, and also protects Raikou from status.

  • Rest with Chesto Berry is a reasonable alternative for giving Raikou more chances to set up Calm Mind.

  • Volt Switch lets Raikou function as a pivot when needed. Extrasensory is mainly for hitting Naganadel as hard as possible.

  • Shadow Ball does good damage to Dragapult, and Aura Sphere can be used if your team has issues with Ferrothorn.

Items

  • Leftovers pairs the best with Calm Mind and Substitute.

  • Life Orb turns Raikou into a more immediate sweeper, and works especially well when Raikou Dynamaxes.

  • Always hold Chesto Berry when using Rest, as Raikou can't afford spending time asleep.

Choice Specs.description:
• Raikou's ability to pivot with Volt Switch, combined with its good Speed stat and coverage, make Choice Specs a reasonable option for it.

  • Extrasensory is Raikou's best attack against Naganadel, while Shadow Ball hits Dragapult hard. Aura Sphere lets Raikou deal a good amount of damage to Ferrothorn, who otherwise walls Raikou.

Suicune.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Calm Mind.description:
• Suicune has some trouble competing with Tapu Fini as a bulky Water-type, but access to tools such as Pressure and a unique movepool give it some niches over the more common Pokemon.

  • Ice Beam is Suicune's most reliable coverage against Dragon-types such as Salamence and Dragapult. Sheer Cold isn't very reliable, but it does give Suicune a 20% chance to OHKO extremely bulky Pokemon such as Tapu Fini and Cresselia, and still gives Suicune a powerful Max Hailstorm.

  • Icy Wind deserves mention for giving Suicune a decent option for Speed control.

  • Air Slash gives Suicune access to Max Airstream, a rare tool for bulky Water-types.

  • Substitute saves Suicune from status moves such as Yawn and Leech Seed, letting it set up on certain passive Pokemon such as Swampert and defensive Celesteela.

  • When paired with Chesto Berry, Rest gives Suicune one chance to recover all its health without much consequence, something Tapu Fini is unable to do.

  • Roar lets Suicune win Calm Mind wars against any Pokemon that lacks Taunt, in addition to phazing set-up sweepers in general before they Dynamax.

  • Protect pairs well with Pressure and Leftovers, letting Suicune scout common choice locked Pokemon such as Rillaboom and Regieleki.

Items

  • Leftovers gives Suicune the most sticking power for its more defensive variants, and pairs well with Substitute and Protect.

  • Sitrus Berry gives Suicune a more immediate burst of health, useful for more offensive variants.

  • Chesto Berry lets Suicune wake up from Rest without wasting a turn.

  • Weakness Policy is an unusual option that lets Calm Mind Suicune take advantage of common checks while Dynamaxed, such as Tapu Koko and Regieleki.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 100 Def / 156 Spe with Bold: This EV spreads outspeeds up to Timid Celesteela, while giving Suicune good physical bulk.

  • 100 HP / 252 SpA / 156 Spe with Modest: This is a more offensive take on Suicune that still outspeeds Timid Celesteela.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Bold: This EV spread maximizes Suicune's physical bulk.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Modest or Timid: This is a far more offensive approach to Suicune, maximizing its power and Speed to take advantage of Max Airstream. Modest gives Suicune some extra fire power and outspeeds up to Timid Tapu Koko after a Max Airstream, while Timid outspeeds Dragapult.

Tyranitar.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Dynamax Attacker.description:
• Tyranitar's incredible special bulk, when combined with Dynamax, allows it to check key special threats, such as Zapdos, Galarian Moltres, and Naganadel. It also has a wide variety of coverage options that can be customized to fit your team's needs.

  • Stone Edge is Tyranitar's most powerful Rock-type STAB. Rock Blast is still a good option to consider, however, being able to break through Disguise and Focus Sash, and having much higher PP.

  • Crunch provides good neutral coverage, and allows Tyranitar to deal massive damage to Cresselia and Metagross.

  • Earthquake gives Tyranitar a useful Special Defense boost when Dynamaxed, OHKOes Dynamaxed Nihilego, and is Tyranitar's best option against Naganadel and Toxapex.

  • Ice Punch is Tyranitar's best option against Landorus-T and Garchomp, dealing massive damage to them both.

  • Iron Head gives Tyranitar a key Defense raise with Max Steelspike, giving it a much better shot of defeating Mimikyu.

  • Superpower lets Tyranitar boost its attack while Dynamaxed with Max Knuckle, and deals insane damage to opposing Tyranitar.

  • Fire Punch allows Tyranitar to roast Ferrothorn, and when Dynamaxed, Max Flare is Tyranitar's most powerful attack against Celesteela.

Items

  • Weakness Policy takes advantage of Tyranitar's large amount of weaknesses, letting it win one-on-one against a wide variety of Pokemon once it gets an Attack boost.

  • Assault Vest enhances Tyranitar's ability to check special attackers, most notably making Tyranitar an excellent check to Naganadel.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe with Adamant: This spread maximizes Tyranitar's power and bulk.

  • 244 HP / 52 Atk / 212 Def with Adamant: This EV spread allows +1 Defense Dynamax Tyranitar to avoid a 2HKO from +2 Life Orb Mimikyu's Play Rough, and also lets Dynamax Tyranitar survive Life Orb Cinderace's Max Knuckle.

Dragon Dance.description:
• With Dragon Dance, Tyranitar patches up its poor Speed stat, allowing it to be a competent and bulky sweeper with a variety of coverage options.

  • Stone Edge is Tyranitar's most powerful STAB with good neutral coverage, but Rock Blast should be considered as well for breaking through Disguise and Focus Sash.

  • Iron Head gives Tyranitar the valuable Max Steelspike when Dynamaxed, which is extremely useful against Mimikyu.

  • Earthquake gives Tyranitar the useful Max Quake for boosting its Special Defense while Dynamaxed, and is also Tyranitar's best option against threats such as Nihilego, Naganadel, and Heatran.

  • Crunch offers good neutral coverage and lets Tyranitar break past Cresselia, and when combined with Iron Head, lets +1 Dynamax Tyranitar potentially beat Dynamax Metagross via Weakness Policy boosts.

  • Ice Punch is Tyranitar's best option against Landorus-T, and deals plenty of damage to Hippowdon while Dynamaxed as well.

  • Fire Punch, when Dynamaxed, deals more damage to Celesteela and Ferrothorn than any other attack as Max Flare.

Items

  • Weakness Policy pairs well with Max Steelspike and Max Quake, and takes advantage of Tyranitar's great bulk while Dynamaxed.

  • Lum Berry protects Tyranitar against status moves such as Yawn and Will-O-Wisp, potentially surprising more passive way to stop a Tyranitar sweep.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 68 Atk / 188 Spe with Jolly: This allows +1 Tyranitar to outspeed up to Adamant Cinderace and Timid Nihilego, while retaining a lot of bulk.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Spe with Jolly: This spread maximizes Tyranitar's Speed and bulk.

  • 84 HP / 204 Atk / 28 Def / 4 SpD / 188 Spe with Jolly: This is a far more offensive approach to the set. The EVs allow Tyranitar to survive a Life Orb Play Rough + Shadow Sneak from Mimikyu, and outspeed Timid Nihilego and Adamant Cinderace after a Dragon Dance.

Support.description:
• With great defensive stats and movepool, Tyranitar makes a good choice for a Stealth Rock setter.

  • Rock Tomb may be weak, but its Speed control is invaluable.

  • Foul Play gets around Tyranitar's potential lack of Attack investment, and notably OHKOs +2 offensive Mimikyu.

  • Taunt lets Tyranitar punish passive Pokemon, such as slower Stealth Rock setters and Porygon2.

  • Earthquake is Tyranitar's best attack against foes such as Heatran, Naganadel, and Nihilego.

  • Thunder Wave provides a more extreme Speed control option, that effectively punishes fast set up sweepers such as Naganadel.

Items

  • Leftovers allows Tyranitar to stick around for a long time, and works particularly well with Taunt.

  • Focus Sash lets Tyranitar get away with a more offensive EV spread, and potentially punish foes that are otherwise safe against it with status such as Cinderace and Urshifu-S.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful: This spread makes Tyranitar as specially bulky as possible, good for special threats such as Zapdos.

  • 84 HP / 140 Atk / 28 Def / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Jolly: This spread is perfect for Focus Sash Tyranitar, maximizing its Speed to take advantage of Speed control, while ensuring that Tyranitar survives Play Rough + Shadow Sneak from Life Orb Mimikyu.

Dynamax Sweeper.description:
EV Spreads

  • 196 HP / 4 Def / 148 SpA / 4 Def / 180 Spe with Timid: The HP investment allows Multiscale Lugia to avoid a 2HKO from non-offensive boosting item Calyrex-S, and outspeed Timid Zapdos.

Paralysis Spreader.description:
EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 108 Def / 148 Spe with Bold: The given Speed allows Lugia to outspeed Calyrex-S after using Max Airstream.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Bold: This spread maximizes Lugia's Defense, making it a more reliable check against Zacian-C that lack Substitute.

  • 252 HP / 36 Def / 220 Spe with Timid: The Speed investment allows Lugia to outspeed up to paralyzed Choice Scarf Calyrex-S.

Ho-Oh.overview: These sets are for one of the final Battle Stadium Singles metagames for this generation. If you feel there is anything wrong or missing, please post in this thread.

Blaziken.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Physical Sweeper.description:
• Blaziken's access to Speed Boost and high powered STAB attacks make it a unique physical sweeper.

  • Protect gives Blaziken a free opportunity to boost its Speed. Replacing Protect with Swords Dance makes it easier to sweep early in the game at the cost of being harder to outspeed foes without using Max Guard from Dynamax.

  • If giving up Swords Dance or Protect, Thunder Punch is good additional coverage, being Blaziken's best attacks against Tapu Fini and Gyarados. Earthquake, in addition to giving a valuable Special Defense boost from Max Quake, is Blaziken's best Attack against Nagandel, Heatran, and Nihilego.

  • Adamant is the prefered nature for damage output, but Jolly allows Blaziken to outspeed Dragapult at +1.

Items

  • Life Orb gives Blaziken the immediate power it usually needs to sweep.

  • Weakness Policy is an acceptable alternative if using Protect, as this can take advantage of opposing Max Moves, and your own Dynamax.

Baton Pass.description:
• Thanks to Speed Boost, Blaziken is one of the best choices around for dedicated Baton Passing.

  • Swords Dance is the quickest route to sweeping, but Bulk Up's Defense boost makes it a useful alternative.

  • Close Combat is Blaziken's most reliable STAB Attack, but note that this means that this Blaziken is hopelessly walled by Ghost-types, although Blaziken should only be attacking in emergencies. Blaze Kick is weak, but a potential solution to that problem.

  • Make sure your team has good Baton Pass recepients. Some Pokemon to consider include Mimikyu, Landorus-T, Dragonite, and Metagross.

Items

  • Focus Sash lets Blaziken set up Swords Dance and Bulk Up on a wider variety of foes.

  • Weakness Policy can take advantage of super-effective Max Moves when used with Protect.

Dynamax Special Attacker.description:
• Blaziken's Special Attack stat is high enough for it to surprise its more physically bulky switch-ins with powerful Special Attacks.

  • Solar Beam is best used when Dynamaxed, dealing massive damage to bulky Water-types such as Tapu Fini, Swampert, and Rotom-W. It also benefits from the Sun Max Flare sets up when Dynamax is over.

  • Protect is still useful before Dynamaxing, getting that all important Speed boost.

  • Scorching Sands not only gives Blaziken a useful Max Quake to boost its Special Defnese, but is also Blaziken's best option against Heatran, Naganadel, and Nihilego. It's also Blaziken's best move against Dragapult.

  • Focus Blast is Blaziken's most powerful special Fighting-type STAB, useful for hitting Porygon2 as hard as possible, at the cost of reliability. Aura Sphere is far more reliable, but is a rather weak move otherwise.

  • Modest is suggested for dealing as much damage as possible, but Timid does allow Blaziken to outspeed Dragapult after one boost.

Items

  • Life Orb is Blaziken's best item for immediate damage, and is also notable for allowing Focus Blast to OHKO physically defensive Porygon2 after Stealth Rock damage.

  • Weakness Policy is a reasonable alternative while Dynamaxed, and it also takes advantage of getting hit by super-effective Max Moves under Protect.

Swampert.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: A- Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are fantastic in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame, and can sweep, support, or wall significant portions of the metagame. These Pokemon require less support than most others to be used effectively and have few flaws that can easily be overlooked when compared to their positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Stealth Rock Setter.description:
• Swampert's good bulk, typing, and access to a slow Flip Turn make it a unique option for Stealth Rock setting.

  • Yawn not only gives Swampert a chance to rack up Stealth Rock damage via switch-outs, but also punishes set-up opportunities againt Swampert, provided that the foe isn't carrying Lum Berry or they aren't a grounded foe in Misty Terrain or Electric Terrain.

  • Earthquake is a reliable STAB that hits high value targets like Nihilego, Heatran, and Naganadel. Ice Beam is a reasonable alternative for hitting Pokemon such as Landorus-T, Dragonite, Salamence, and Garchomp much harder.

  • Damp is an important ability for blocking Explosion, making Swampert a particularly good check to Regieleki. Torrent is still usable for boosting Flip Turn when Swampert is low on health, however.

  • The given EV spread maximizes Swampert's physical bulk, while making it as slow as possible for Flip Turn.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry gives Swampert the fastest burst of recovery possible,

  • Rindo Berry is a good alternative for allowing Swampert to survive weaker Grass-type attacks, such as Nihilego's boosted Grass Knot.

  • Focus Sash may seem absurd with Swampert's bulk, but it lets Swampert reliably use Yawn against Dynamax Pokemon, and set up Stealth Rock without worry if needed.

Wonder Guard.description:
• Despite meager stats across the board, Shedinja finds a place on teams as a defensive pivot thanks to its unique ability, Wonder Guard. This enables Shedinja to wall any Pokemon that can't fit a move to hit it for super effective damage, such as most Kyogre, Xerneas, and Zacian-C.

  • Poltergeist is Shedinja's strongest STAB move, dealing respectable damage to most neutral foes and revealing the target's held item. Use this move liberally to gather information about opponents' sets and scout for items like Rocky Helmet, which will KO Shedinja using Shadow Sneak or X-Scissor. Scouting items is especially effective in the Battle Stadium format due to the Item Clause, which allows for a process of elimination to deduce other foes' items.

  • Will-O-Wisp allows Shedinja to burn incoming physical attackers looking to KO it, making them easier to deal with for teammates.

  • Shadow Sneak lets Shedinja revenge kill faster foes that have been sufficiently weakened.

  • Endure allows Shedinja to scout for super effective attacks, including surprise Max Moves, and is particularly useful if not utilizing a Focus Sash. Use Endure liberally, as teams that appear to be weak to Shedinja at first glance may have surprise coverage options to overcome it.

  • X-Scissor is an alternative to Endure that lets Shedinja hit Dark-types super effectively and keeps Normal-types from completely walling it, but it won't be able to scout for fatal coverage. Even with X-Scissor, Shedinja still will not deal much damage to most Normal- and Dark-types, so teammates that can handle them make for great partners. Urshifu-R can both threaten them and the majority of entry hazard setters in the metagame, which threaten to instantly KO Shedinja switching in unless it's holding Heavy-Duty Boots.

  • Protect may seem appealing instead of Endure, further allowing Shedinja to scout for moves like Leech Seed, Toxic, and Will-O-Wisp. However, it leaves Shedinja vulnerable to Max Moves, making Endure the superior option in most cases.

  • A Lonely nature, along with 0 IVs in Defense and Special Defense, is chosen to improve the matchup against Ditto, since Shedinja can't benefit from bulk investment itself.

Items

  • Focus Sash allows Shedinja to survive one super effective attack without having to use Endure, but it leaves Shedinja vulnerable to any form of indirect damage.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Shedinja from fainting to entry hazard damage. Notably, it can let Shedinja wall hazard setters reliant on Stealth Rock to take it out, such as Swampert and Mamoswine lacking Rock Tomb. If not running Heavy-Duty Boots, Shedinja's team absolutely needs a plan for dealing with common entry hazard setters.

  • Safety Goggles is the only way to prevent hail and sand damage from KOing Shedinja, which can be invaluable against teams with Tyranitar, Hippowdon, or potential users of Max Hailstorm and Max Rockfall.

Salamence.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: A Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are fantastic in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame, and can sweep, support, or wall significant portions of the metagame. These Pokemon require less support than most others to be used effectively and have few flaws that can easily be overlooked when compared to their positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Physical Sweeper.description:
• Salamence is a very threatening Max Airstream sweeper, with just enough coverage to make it difficult to check with defensive Pokemon.

  • Dual Wingbeat is the clear choice over Fly for a Flying-type STAB, as it's more reliable outside of Dynamax, and its multi-hit nature is useful against frail Focus Sash Pokemon such as Pheromosa.

  • Fire Blast is highly recommended for hitting Celesteela as hard as possible when Dynamaxed. Fire Fang, while very weak on its own, can make sense on Moxie Salamence as a powerful Fire-type Attack under Dynamax.

  • Earthquake is also highly valuable for hitting other Steel-types hard such as Heatran and Metagross.

  • Although this makes Salamence walled by certain Pokemon, some coverage can be given up to slot in Dragon Dance, which makes Salamence less reliant on Dynamaxing to sweep.

  • Moxie is the ability of choice, letting Salamence kickstart a sweep with a simple KO, especially from Max Airstream. Intimidate is still a reasonable alternative, allowing Salamence to set up Dragon Dance or Weakness Policy more easily.

Items

  • Life Orb Salamence's best option for immediate power while Dynamaxed.

  • Weakness Policy is an acceptable alternative that takes advantate of Intimidate quite well.

  • Lum Berry is particularly useful for Dragon Dance Salamence, as this makes it less worried about status.

Special Attacker.description:
• While its Special Attack is lower than its Attack, Salamence's high base power moves and access to Intimidate and STAB Max Airstream make it a fully capable Special Attacker.

  • Hurricane allows Salamence to be at its most dangerous when Dynamaxed, especially when Salamence can set up its own rain to guarantee its accuracy. Air Slash is still a reasonable alternative as a more reliable Flying-type STAB.

  • Fire Blast and Hydro Pump are important for covering Steel-types such as Celesteela and Heatran. Note, however, that while Salamence is Dynamaxed, the weathers they set up will weaken the other move.

Items

  • Life Orb allows Salamence to deal as much damage as possible, and is less reliant on Dynamax.

  • Weakness Policy is a reasonable alternative to focus more on Dynamax sweeping.

Metagross.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: A- Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are fantastic in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame, and can sweep, support, or wall significant portions of the metagame. These Pokemon require less support than most others to be used effectively and have few flaws that can easily be overlooked when compared to their positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Dynamax Attacker.description:
• Metagross's great bulk and typing make it a very solid choice for Dynamaxing, with Max Steelspike making it particularly difficult to KO.

  • Earthquake is very useful for gaining a Special Defense boost via Max Quake, and hitting opposing Steel-types hard.

  • Thunder Punch is mainly useful for dealing as much damage to Celesteela and Corviknight as possible.

  • Hammer Arm lets Metagross boost its Attack while Dynamaxed with Max Knuckle, and still hits Heatran and Ferrothorn decently hard.

  • Zen Headbutt is Metagross's most powerful STAB when Psychic Terrain is up, and it severely damages Urshifu-R and the rare Toxapex.

  • Bullet Punch is a useful priority move to carry when not Dynamaxed.

  • Although giving up an attack is difficult, Agility is notable for allowing Metagross to potentially sweep late-game.

Items

  • Weakness Policy is the obvious choice as a Dynamax attacker, punishing foes that dare hit Metagross super-effectively.

  • Assault Vest is a reasonable alternative that makes Metagross even more difficult to KO with Special Attacks.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe with Adamant: This EV spread mazimizes Metagross's bulk and Attack stat.

  • 164 HP / 252 Atk / 92 Spe with Adamant: When used with Agility, this EV spread allows Metagross to outspeed up to neutral natured Pheromosa.

  • 68 HP / 252 Atk / 188 Spe with Jolly: This EV spread allows Metagross to outspeed Timid Celesteela, which is very useful when running Thunder Punch.

  • 44 HP / 252 Atk / 212 Spe with Jolly: When using Agility, this Speed investment allows Metagross to outspeed up to +1 Nihilego, +1 Garchomp, and max Speed neutral natured Regieleki.

Kyogre.overview: These sets are for one of the final Battle Stadium Singles metagames for this generation. If you feel there is anything wrong or missing, please post in this thread.

Bulky Assault Vest.description:
EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD: This is the standard EV spread for maximizing Kyogre's bulk and power.

  • 252 HP / 196 SpA / 60 Spe: This EV spread allows Kyogre to outspeed important paralyzed threats, such as Zacian-C and opposing Choice Scarf Kyogre.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe: The Speed investment allows Kyogre to outpace up to Jolly Necrozma-DM, at the cost of potentially being 2HKOed by mixed Dynamax Yveltal while Kyogre is under Dynamax.

Choice Specs.description:
EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with Modest: This EV spread is used when your team does not have paralysis support.

  • 196 HP / 252 SpA / 60 Spe with Modest: This EV spread allows Kyogre to outspeed important paralyzed threats, such as Zacian-C and opposing Choice Scarf Kyogre.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid This spread will speed tie with dangerous base 90 Speed threats, such as Zekrom and Dialga.

Groudon.overview: These sets are for one of the final Battle Stadium Singles metagames for this generation. If you feel there is anything wrong or missing, please post in this thread.

Support.description:
Items

  • Light Ball: When paired with Fling, this lets Groudon paralyze foes while breaking through Focus Sash, paralyze Ground-types, and bypass Taunt.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry gives Groudon a chance to turn some 2HKOs into 3HKOs, such as Zacian-C's Behemoth Blade when using a physically defensive spread.

  • Custap Berry: Groudon often gets into the activation range for Custap Berry, letting it get one last attack in before going down. This can be paired with Endure for more reliable activation, at the cost of coverage or paralysis spreading.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 196 SpD / 60 Spe with Careful: This EV spread lets Groudon avoid an OHKO from Modest Life Orb Yveltal's Max Darkness, while outspeeding up to Choice Scarf Kyogre after paralysis.

  • 252 HP / 76 Atk / 116 Def / 4 SpD / 60 Spe with Impish: This spread allows Groudon to avoid a 2HKO from Adamant Zacian-C's Behemoth Blade with Sitrus Berry, while still outspeeding Choice Scarf Kyogre after paralysis.

  • 252 HP / 196 Atk / 60 Spe with Adamant: A more offensive spread is a suitable option for Custap variants, and makes Groudon a better Dynamax user.

Jirachi.overview: This set is for one of the final Battle Stadium Singles metagames for this generation. If you feel there is anything wrong or missing, please post in this thread.

Gastrodon.overview: These sets are for a new and developing metagame. If you have any questions about the sets, feel free to ask any in the Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Discussion thread.

Specially Defensive.description:
• With Storm Drain and its part-Ground typing, Gastrodon is one of the better switch-ins to Choice item Kyogre sets.

  • Earth Power can be used in place of Counter to hit Zacian-C super effectively, heavily damaging it without relying on Gastrodon itself getting hit first. It also can punish a Zacian-C trying to grab a free switch on Mirror Coat.

  • Yawn can help play around Dynamax sweepers like Zapdos, forcing them out and potentially allowing Gastrodon to get a vital Recover off. It should be used carefully, however, as Max Starfall users can bypass its effect.

  • Mirror Coat can be used to more immediately pressure the special attackers Gastrodon will be walling, but it comes at the cost of some longevity. Additionally, Mirror Coat does not affect Dark-types, such as Yveltal.

  • Earthquake can be used over Earth Power to hit Kyogre harder, which helps against Substitute and Calm Mind variants.

  • Gastrodon can potentially be used as a wincon via timer stalling, though this is not a use to rely on consistently. If attempting this, consider using a shiny Gastrodon to whittle down the timer more on every switch-in.

Items

  • Leftovers is preferred to augment Gastrodon’s longevity, allowing it to passively heal from lesser damage sources like Stealth Rock. Sitrus Berry is an alternative longevity option.

  • Rindo Berry can be useful to survive surprise Grass-type attacks aimed at Gastrodon.

EV Spreads

  • 228 HP / 180 Def / 100 SpD with Calm - This prevents the 2HKO from Modest Ice Beam from Choice Specs Kyogre, as well as avoiding the OHKO from Adamant Zacian-C’s Play Rough and Choice Band Urshifu-S’s Wicked Blow, barring a maximum damage roll from the latter. However, it comes at the cost of some resilience against Zapdos and Yveltal.

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpD with Calm - This spread maximizes Gastrodon’s special bulk but leaves it heavily threatened by strong physical attackers.

Physically Defensive.description:
• This set maximizes Gastrodon’s physical bulk, allowing it to act as a sort of mixed wall, being somewhat competent against threats like Zacian-C while maintaining effectiveness against Choice item Kyogre variants.

  • Counter and Mirror Coat are used in tandem with Focus Sash to potentially trade with massive threats, such as Landorus-T, Zacian-C, Zapdos, and Urshifu-S.

  • Earth Power can be useful against Zacian-C, punishing it on the switch and getting around potential Counter mind games.

  • Yawn can be used to annoy setup and utility-based Pokemon, but it does make Gastrodon more vulnerable to Taunt. Additionally, Dynamax users with Fairy-type attacks can use Max Starfall to block sleep.

Items

  • Focus Sash is the preferred item, allowing Gastrodon to get maximum value out of both Counter and Mirror Coat.

  • If running Yawn or Earth Power, consider Leftovers or Sitrus Berry for slightly more longevity.

  • Rindo Berry can also be used to potentially save Gastrodon from a surprise Grass-type attack.

Garchomp.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Swords Dance Sweeper.description:
• With a unique Speed tier and good coverage, Garchomp is a solid choice as a sweeper.

  • Scale Shot doesn't deal the most consistent damage, but the Speed boost makes Garchomp harder to revenge kill, and it still becomes a strong Max Wyrmwind while Dynamaxed.

  • Fire Fang may be weak, but after a Swords Dance boost, it's Garchomp's best option against Celesteela, especially if Garchomp Dynamaxes.

Items

  • Focus Sash lets Garchomp set up Swords Dance more consistently, though it doesn't protect it from Icicle Spear from the likes of Glastrier and Mamoswine.

  • Lum Berry protects Garchomp from status, so Yawn and Will-O-Wisp won't stop its sweep.

  • Life Orb's power boost is very valuable when Garchomp Dynamaxes, and makes it less reliant on setting up Swords Dance to sweep.

Stealth Rock Setter.description:
• Garchomp's good bulk, power, and Speed make it a reasonable option for setting up Stealth Rock.

  • Rock Tomb provides Speed control for the team, which is especially valauble against Max Airstream users like Zapdos and Galarian Moltres.

  • If using Swords Dance, consider Scale Shot instead to increase Garchomp's chances of cleaning late-game.

  • Outrage is a risky, but powerful STAB for Garchomp to use.

  • Focus Sash gives Garchomp the best chance of setting up Stealth Rock.

Choice Scarf.description:
• Garchomp's Speed tier makes it good choice for revenge killing with Choice Scarf.

  • Outrage may be a risky STAB due to locking Garchomp in, but outspeeding and slamming slower Dragon-types such as Salamence with it is extremely valuable.

  • Rock Tomb may be weak, but it allows Garchomp to sacrifice itself for Speed control against Max Airstream sweepers. Stone Edge and Rock Slide are more powerful alternatives, especially if Garchomp is forced to Dynamax.

  • Iron Head doesn't hit Mimikyu that much harder than Earthquake, but when Garchomp is forced to Dynamax, the Defense boost from Max Steelspike is very useful.

Hippowdon.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: A+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are fantastic in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame, and can sweep, support, or wall significant portions of the metagame. These Pokemon require less support than most others to be used effectively and have few flaws that can easily be overlooked when compared to their positive traits.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Support.description:
• Hippowdon is one of the most reliable defensive Stealth Rock setters in the metagame. Compound this with Yawn, and Hippowdon can force a lot of chip damage by switching foes into Stealth Rock.

  • Whirlwind not only takes advantage of Stealth Rock being set, but it can also force out irritating Substitute users such as Celesteela.

  • Slack Off allows Hippowdon to truly become a wall, sticking around far longer than usual at the cost of some extra utility otherwise.

  • Ice Fang allows Hippowdon to deal good damage to several Flying-types, such as Landorus-T and Salamence.

  • Rock Tomb gives Hippowdon Speed control support.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry is the most reliable way for Hippowdon to get a quick burst of health back.

  • Figy Berry gives back more health than Sitrus Berry, but it activating at lower health can be awkward in certain match-ups.

  • If using Slack Off, consider a Kee Berry, as this makes Hippowdon less vulnerable to Cinderace sweeps.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with Impish: This spread maximizes Hippowdon's physically defensive capabilities.

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpD with Careful: Specially defensive Hippowdon can be used to survive unexpected moves, potentially gaining an edge early in the game.

Magnezone.overview:
This analysis covers a newly introduced Pokemon. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Special Attacker.description:
• With a unique typing and set of abilities, Magnezone has a niche for being a bulky offensive Electric-type.

  • Sturdy gives Magnezone a Focus Sash like effect and makes it immune to deadly OHKO moves. Alternately, Analytic works well since Magnezone usually moves second, giving it a good boost in power.

  • Steel Beam is Magnezone's strongest attack by far, but the cost of losing half its health means it should be used sparringly.

  • Mirror Coat takes advantage of Sturdy, allowing Magnezone to potentially get a surprise KO on common Special Attacking Dynamaxers.

  • Body Press is Magnezone's best option against Ferrothorn, Raikou, and opposing Magnezone.

  • Endure should be used with Custap Berry, giving Magnezone another chance to activate it if Sturdy has been used up, or if Magnezone is using Analytic.

Items

  • Assault Vest gives Magnezone a good amount of special bulk, especially if it's forced to Dynamax.

  • Choice Specs gives Magnezone a ton of firepower as a hit-and-run attacker, and works especially well with taking advantage of Volt Switch.

  • Custap Berry gives Magnezone once chance to have an attack with increased prirotity when it's low on health, which pairs especially well with Sturdy.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 Spe with Modest: This spread maximizes Magnezone's bulk and power.

  • 4 HP / 252 Def / 252 SpA with Modest: This spread is to be used with Body Press, to maximize that move's power.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Modest: Magnezone may not be fast, but investing in Speed can allow it to get the jump on bulky foes that don't always bother to, such as Celesteela.

Stall Breaker.description:
• With Iron Defense and Body Press, Magnezone can be an effective tool against stall teams.

  • Substitute and Leftovers protects Magnezone from status, and can effectively scout potentially problematic switch-ins.

  • Magnet Pull seriously punishes defensive Steel-types on stall teams by trapping them, but Sturdy is a more reliable option otherwises, in case Magnezone faces a threat that might OHKO it.

Rhyperior.overview: These sets are for a new and developing metagame. If you have any questions about the sets, feel free to ask any in the Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Discussion thread.

Mamoswine.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Stealth Rock Setter.description:
• Mamoswine is an effective early game setter of Stealth Rock with Focus Sash, thanks to its good coverage and access to priority in Ice Shard.

  • Icicle Spear is the prefered Ice-type STAB, since it breaks through Focus Sash and Mimikyu's Disguise.

  • Oblivious blocks the effects of Intimidate and Taunt, making it Mamoswine's best ability.

Porygon-Z.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B- Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Special Wallbreaker.description:
• Porygon-Z's high base Special Attack coupled with Adaptability and great coverage allows it to break down or outright sweep a variety of slower opposing team compositions.

  • Tri Attack or Uproar can be used as an alternative STAB options to Hyper Beam that do not have cooldown, whereas Thunderbolt provides solid coverage against the likes of Celesteela and Water-types such as Tapu Fini and Gyarados.

  • Nasty Plot allows Porygon-Z to boost its Special Attack to nearly unwallable levels, whereas Trick allows it to cripple passive walls and regain move flexibility.

Items

  • Chopple Berry lets Porygon-Z survive Fighting-type Attacks while Dynamaxed, particularly useful against Cinderace and Urshifu-R.

  • Life Orb lets Porygon-Z deal massive damage even without a Nasty Plot boost.

  • Choice Scarf patches up Porygon-Z's Speed stat, letting it outspeed key threats such as Dragapult and Choice Scarf Dracovish.

Rotom-Heat.overview:
This analysis covers a Pokemon in a very new metagame. The metagame may shift rapidly. If you have any suggestions for this analysis, please post them in the current Battle Stadium Singles Analysis Thread.

Viability Ranking: B+ Rank

Reserved for Pokemon that are great in the Battle Stadium Singles metagame. These Pokemon have more notable flaws than those above them that affect how they function in the format. Their positive traits still outshine their negatives, but they require a bit more team support to bring out their full potential.

For more information on viability rankings, check out the full rankings here.

Choice.description:
• Rotom-H sports a fantastic defensive typing, and serves as a premier offensive pivot with good defensive upside.

  • Rotom-H often choses Trick and Will-O-Wisp as defensive move options to cripple defensive walls or physical Dynamax sweepers at the expensive of offensive coverage
